Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Climate and Glacier change in Bhutan: the last millennia, present and future
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will provide robust information about past, present and future glacier and climate change in the Kingdom of Bhutan, in the southeastern monsoonal Himalayas, and contribute to a more robust scientific platform for decision makers and mitigation strategists. Knowing the rate of glacier retreat in response to climate change is fundamental for any prediction of future behavior and in turn to design adaption and mitigation strategies for societies. However, this rate remains poorly constrained. Bhutan's welfare is linked to glacier dynamics because hydropower generation and agricultural irrigation are fueled by glacier melt. Melting glaciers and the steep relief have made glacial lake outburst floods a prime hazard for the societies of Bhutan and its Himalayan neighbors, and the hazard potential critically depends on current and future glacier melt.

This is an integrated research and education project, combining geomorphology, geochronology, paleo-thermometry, glaciology, and glacier modeling to reconstruct glacier and climate change over the last millennia, and to predict Himalayan glacier change over the next century. This is a multi-disciplinary team of experts with broad experience in Himalayan glacier and climate problems, including a female junior faculty at a primarily undergraduate institution and a special-needs MS student.

This is a US-Bhutan bilateral research and educational proposal, with the Department of Hydromet Services/Ministry of Economic Affairs (DHMS) as the official Bhutanese collaborator, and with the Ugyen Wangchuck Institute for Conservation and Environment (UWICE) as the educational partner. Bhutanese students will train in geomorphic mapping (remote and field based) and tree-ring techniques. Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory will host UWICE students and DHMS and Columbia University's Earth Institute will host UWICE scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmental change in the Himalayas impacts societies in the most densely populated, and some of the poorest, areas on earth. Rapid glacier retreat in Bhutan, monsoonal Himalayas, affecting river discharge and, in turn, energy production and agriculture, is a particularly worrisome example. Bhutan's welfare is directly linked to glacier dynamics because hydropower generation, the primary source of income, and agricultural irrigation, is fueled by glacier melt. Melting glaciers and the steep relief have also made GLOFs a prime hazard for the societies of Bhutan and their Himalayan neighbors, and the hazard potential in space and time critically depends on current and future glacier melt. The rate of glacier retreat in Bhutan, in response to climate change, is fundamental for any prediction of future behavior and in turn to design adaption and mitigation strategies for societies. However, this rate has historically remained poorly constrained, limiting adaptation and mitigation strategies. Through close collaboration between all PIs and our Bhutanese partners, we quantify the rate of glacier changes over time, the dominant drivers of this change, and the impact on downstream water resources. In particular, we show that (1) glaciers in Bhutan begin their most recent retreat in the mid 1800s A.D., (2) the rate of glacier mass loss has doubled in the most recent 15 years relative to the preceding decades and century, (3) temperature is the dominant driving force for these glacier changes, and (4) temperature will dominate glacier mass loss in the coming century. The combination of data and numerical modeling has greatly improved our ability to assess glacier contributions to water resources under future climate scenarios. Our results show that glacier contributions to water resources will increase, reaching a maximum around 2040-50. Glacier meltwater discharge will then decrease significantly, reaching minimum by 2100. The outcomes of this work are the direct result of the integration of geomorphology, geochronology, paleo-thermometry, and glaciology. And we are drafting a policy brief - collaboratively written with our Bhutanese colleagues, for Bhutanese policy-makers - based on these new findings. 

                Throughout these research efforts, numerous students and Bhutanese colleagues have been trained in glaciological field work, statistical data analysis, numerical modeling, and interdisciplinary research. This training has occurred through targeted field campaigns in Bhutan, workshops and symposium held at Columbia University and in Bhutan, and collaborative meetings at conferences and at our respective institutions. In addition, the results of this work have been broadly disseminated to the research community and general public through scientific publications, conference presentations, media interviews, and public lectures.
